title: Dracula trailer: 7 things we’re excited to see in the new BBC series
text:
It looks terrifying (Picture: BBC)

Dracula is expected to premiere on the BBC One this winter.

Dracula is returning to the TV screens in what might be the best adaptation of Bram Stoker’s 19th century horror novel with Mark Gatiss and Steven Moffat (Sherlock) at the helm.

A terrifying, gore-filled teaser trailer of the BBC and Netflix co-production has just dropped, and already people are excited about the titular Count, who will be played by Danish actor Claes Bang.

There isn’t much information about the three-part series, but what we do know is that it will follow canon at least in the onset, and will start off in Transylvania in 1897, where Count Dracula is conspiring to travel to Victorian London in search of fresh blood.

Claes appears to be sticking somewhat to canon in Dracula’s look (Picture: BBC)

If the clip is anything to go by, the series will be a terrifying mix of blood, gore, satanic, knife-brandishing nuns and of course, the creepy vampire.

No Edward Cullens here.

The series is set to be released sometime this winter, and while we wait for the weather to align with the cold, eerie setting of the Carpathian mountains, here are some things we’re looking forward to seeing:

Claes Bang as Dracula

Dracula is a role that has been played by over a dozen actors in over a century; from Rudolph Martin’s portrayal in Buffy The Vampire Slayer to Bela Lugosi in Dracula (1931) to Duncan Regehr’s depiction of Dracula in The Monster Squad (1897), actors have taken the role and made it their own.

The BBC miniseries will be shown later on this year (Picture: BBC)

How will Claes fair?

Claes has a strong theatre background, having graduated from the Danish National School of Theatre in 1996, and followed a stage career in Denmark and later transitioned to TV.

With a history in theatre, we can expect a dramatic, arresting depiction of Dracula filled with brooding looks and pregnant pauses.

He’s won a number of prestigious awards including the Palm D’Or at the 2017 Cannes Film Festival for his portrayal of museum curator Christian in Ruben Ostlund’s film The Square, as well as being the first Dane to win the European Film Award for Best Actor.

The script

The new BBC adaption was created by two powerhouse writers: Mark Gatiss and Steven Moffat.

The pair worked together on the wildly successful Sherlock series, and both carry hefty acting and writing credentials.

We don’t know why there are nuns. But bring the nuns (Picture: BBC)

Gatiss has penned episodes in Doctor Who, Sherlock as well as a handful of films, whilst Moffat worked alongside him on Sherlock, as well as Jekyll, Doctor Who and the Adventures of Tintin, to name a few.

Advertisement

We can only imagine what they’ve brewed up together.

The Aesthetics

The series will be set in Victorian England and Transylvania: think elaborate dog collars and beautiful dresses against a gothic, brooding backdrop.

With technological advances in CGI and film production, it’ll be interesting to see how the series will show the supernatural elements of the series. Gone are the days of plastic vampire teeth, over-done makeup and visible wires.

We hope.

Iconic scene with the Three Sisters

One of the most iconic scenes in the book is when English solicitor Jonathan Harker (played by John Heffernan in the BBC One adaptation) accidentally stumbles across three female vampires called the Three Sisters, who seduce and almost devour him before he is rescued by Dracula.

Who will play Dracula’s enemy?

Abraham Van Helsing is the man who hunts down Dracula and is part of the party who kills him. He’s another character who has stood the test of time and has been played by dozens of actors in dozens of contexts. How the writers will introduce his character remains to be seen.

Advertisement

Depending on the Dracula adaptation, Van Helsing has been an occult specialist, a hunter, a doctor. In this BBC adaptation, will Dracula and Van Helsing’s relationship be similar to that of Villanelle and Eve Polastri in Killing Eve?

How will Lucy Westenra fare in the new series?

Lucy is the manifestation of good in Dracula’s dark world, and she is an iconic character in the story. In most iterations of the story she ends up being stalked, and later turned into a vampire by Dracula. Her fall prerequisites his, and we wonder who will play Lucy, and what her character will be to Dracula.

We want to know.

What about the original story’s deleted ending?

In the original manuscript draft of the final chapter, Dracula’s castle falls apart after he dies. Will this be something Moffat and Gatiss will depict, or will they use their artistic licence to come up with a more sinister ending?

Dracula is set to air on BBC One in the UK and on Netflix outside of the UK and Ireland.
